exceptions.exception: This is a wrapper exception for other exceptions. In general, you should not see it. If you see it, this means that there is a bug in our exception displaying code. :-)

{product_name} encountered unexpected internal error.
This could be caused by a {product_name} bug or by a misconfiguration issue, conflict, partial update, etc.

Incomplete product installation or upgrade detected. Please install or update the entire product. If the problem persists, un-install and re-install the entire product. Also ensure that the Eclipse JDT and PDE are fully installed as required by the system requirements.

Congratulations! You found a case that we know about, however have not implemented support for it yet. Please report to support what you did and why this is important for you, and we will try to implement this feature.
Your current source contains one or more compilation problems. Please see the Eclipse Problems view and resolve them before trying to edit the class with {product_name}.

The parser parsed the compilation unit, but can't identify any GUI toolkit, so {product_name} can't display any GUI to edit. This can be caused by one of the following reasons:
This class is not an editable UI class and contains no UI components.
{product_name} does not recognize the GUI toolkit or library used in this class.
{product_name} does not understand this GUI type/pattern in a supported GUI toolkit.
Problems exist with the classpath. For example, the compilation unit uses SWT classes, but the SWT/JFace libraries are not included into the classpath.
The wrong format is being used to describe non visual beans [format: @wbp.nonvisual location=X,Y]: {0}

exception.title: Graphical editing is not provided for factory classes/methods.
exception.pre: Please use the Source page to make any changes.

exceptions.exception:
Compilation unit {0} has no primary type. This can be caused by one of the following reasons:
Compilation unit is empty because it was not fully created by wizard.
It has type(s) with other name(s) than name of the compilation unit.

Eclipse is running under {1}, but this Java project has a {0} Java compliance level, so {product_name} will not be able to load classes from this project. Use a lower level of Java for the project, or run Eclipse using a newer Java version.

{product_name} was unable to load class {0} that is used as super class for your form. This usually happens when:
Compilation unit has compilation problems.
Super class is in project, but automatic build is turned off.

Compilation unit {0} has primary type, but {product_name} can not find its AST. This can be caused by one of the following reasons:
Compilation unit references unknown type, most probably as part of generics.

exception.title: This is not a GUI class and can't be edited graphically

exceptions.exception:
The parser parsed the compilation unit, but can't identify any GUI toolkit.
Possible reasons:
You open a compilation unit without any GUI, such as an empty class, data bean, etc.
Classpath of project is not valid, does not include all required toolkit libraries.
You attempt to open UI for toolkit, support for which is not installed in WindowBuilder.
Use button Show UI Toolkits to install new toolkit.

ASTEditor (internal class for source/ASTNode's manipulations) found a problem while replacing a substring in the compilation unit source code. This problem can be caused by prior problems in AST manipulations.

{product_name} can not access type or binding information about variable {0}. This usually happens when compilation unit has compilation problems, such as:
Declaring any field with unknown type.
Declaring variable with unknown type on execution flow.

{product_name} can not access type binding information for node {0}. This usually happens when compilation unit has compilation problems. Possible reasons and solutions:
Using not existing types.
Not all required libraries are included into Java project.
Organize imports should be done to import required types by their fully qualified names.

{product_name} was not able to parse source {0}.
{1}
Possible reasons:
Using old versions of libraries in your Java project.
Not all required dependencies exist in your Java project.
Compilation errors in your Java project.
Use of conflicting variable name such as com, org, net, edu, java, or javax.
Bug in {product_name}.

{product_name} was not able to find plugin {0}. Possible reasons:
Not all required dependencies exist in your Eclipse.
Bug in {product_name}.
{0} is not valid source for component creation, it does not reference existing type.
{0} is not valid source for component creation, it references not existing constructor.
The AST evaluation engine was unable to evaluate the expression '{0}'. This can be caused by many problems - compilation errors, unsupported code structures, etc.
The AST evaluation engine was unable to find the variable (SimpleName) with name '{0}'. This can be caused by many problems - compilation errors, unsupported code structures, etc.

exception.title: No method invocation
exception.p: The AST evaluation engine was unable to find an invocation of the method

As a result, the engine can't evaluate the values of the parameter '{1}' of this method. Depending on the context where these parameters are used, they can:
be ignored, for example, "button.setText(unknownParameter)"
cause a parsing exception, for example, when a parameter is required to create a component instance - "new JButton(unknownParameter)"
You can use the "@wbp.eval.method.parameter {parameter name} {Java expression}" JavaDoc tag to force the value of the parameter, so your code will be evaluated even if the method is not invoked.
Note that you can use any valid Java expressions, including operators, invocations of static methods, etc.

exceptions.exception:
The method {0}
is invoked in the following places: {1}.
As a result, {product_name} can't decide which one to use.
Maybe you should consider extracting this method into a separate static/instance factory class.
{product_name} can't invoke the local instance method {0}.

An exception happened during evaluation of
{0} Method {1} was used with the parameters {2}.

exception.title: Exception during super method invocation evaluation

exceptions.exception:
An exception happened
		during evaluation of
{0} Method {1} was used with the parameters {2}.
		{3}

exception.title: Unable to create 'this' component. Non-public constructor.

exceptions.exception: Your top level component calls a non-public constructor {0}. Normally, {product_name} uses CGLib to create a superclass instance. However CGLib can't call non-public constructors (at least in different ClassLoaders), so make the constructor public so that it can be rendered in {product_name}.

exception.title: Expression part of invocation is null.

exceptions.exception:
Expression part of invocation {0} was evaluated into null. Possible reasons and solutions:
You use some object that really evaluates to null at design time, for example not initialized singletons, no required environment, etc.
Evaluation of expression at the end requires some parameter passed into constructor. By default {product_name} gives all parameters default value (false, zero or null). You can use JavaDoc tag on constructor @wbp.eval.method.parameter obj new SomeObject() to set better value. See documentation for details.
In any case, you always can use code hiding (see documentation) or Beans.isDesignTime().
An exception happened during evaluation of constructor {0} using arguments {1}. {2}
{product_name} was not able to find constructor with signature {0} in {1}.

exception.title: Anonymous class creation can not be evaluated.

exceptions.exception: In general case it is impossible to evaluate creation of anonymous class. So, expression {0} was not evaluated.

{product_name} couldn't find the description (*.wbp-component.xml file) for the component with class {0}. In general, {product_name} contains descriptions for all supported GUI components. Even if some component doesn't have a direct description, the description for its super class can be used (to some extent, for example, constructors require specific descriptions). It is expected that {product_name} will not try to ask for descriptions for components that can't be found. Please send a test case to support.
{product_name} found a problem in the configurable static field editor: {0}.

For component {0}.
Check root exception for details.
{product_name} does not know the GUI toolkit used for : {0}. You may be trying to open something unsupported by {product_name}.

exception.title: No support for this Operating System found

exceptions.exception:
{product_name} did not find the plug-in supporting the Operating System and/or Windowing System that you are using. In most cases this is caused by an incorrect, incomplete or corrupted installation.
Please try re-installing the complete product into a clean Eclipse environment.
